block.p: U.S. Extends Troops' Tours In Iraq and Afghanistan The military announced that most active-duty Army units now in Iraq and Afghanistan and those sent in the future will serve 15-month tours, three months longer than the standard tour.

Arms that American military officials say appear to have been manufactured in Iran as recently as last year have turned up in the past week in a Sunni-majority area, the chief spokesman for the American military command in Iraq said in a news conference.

Bombings Kill 23 in Algeria Two bombings in Algeria, one aimed at the main government building in the capital, killed at least 23 people in a sharp escalation of the violence linked to Al Qaeda that has been spreading across North Africa in recent months.

Documents Give Glimpse of War Hundreds of claims submitted to the Army by Iraqi and Afghan civilians seeking payment for noncombat killings, injuries or property damage inflicted by American forces display the chaos faced by bystanders and troops in the two war zones.
Chinese Leader Visits Japan Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China began a three-day visit to Japan, in what both countries described as an important step forward in repairing diplomatic relations.

All Charges Dropped In Duke University Case The attorney general of North Carolina dropped all charges against three former Duke University lacrosse players who had been accused of raping a stripper, ending a prosecution that provoked debate over race, class and the tactics of the Durham County district attorney.

New Light on Voter Fraud Data Five years after the Bush administration began a crackdown on voter fraud, the Justice Department has turned up virtually no evidence of any organized effort to skew federal elections, according to court records and interviews.

Panel Criticizes Walter Reed An independent panel assessing dilapidated facilities and red tape for wounded Iraq war veterans at Walter Reed Army Medical Center issued an indictment of leadership failures, inadequate training and staffing shortages.

New Health Care Proposal Massachusetts is poised to be the first state to make it possible for 99 percent of adults to be covered by health insurance with a plan that sets limits for the premiums people should be expected to pay. State officials said that under the plan, they expected that all but about 65,000 of the 328,000 adults who are currently uninsured would be able to get affordable coverage. A14

City Seeks Right to Force Repairs on Idle Landlords A bill to be introduced in the New York City Council with the Bloomberg administration's support would give the Department of Housing Preservation and Development broad new powers to overhaul entire building systems in long-troubled properties and force landlords to pay for the work. B1

States Join Forces on Mercury New York and six other Northeastern states announced that they had joined in a regional pact to try to force the federal government to enact tougher standards on mercury emissions. B5
NBC Drops Imus Show NBC News dropped Don Imus, canceling his show from its MSNBC cable news channel after he made racially disparaging remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team.

Citigroup to Cut Jobs Citigroup, which has long carried the mantle as the world's biggest bank, said that it would shed or move more than 26,500 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force in an effort to cut expenses. About 1,600 jobs will be eliminated in New York City, where Citigroup has its headquarters.
Editorials: Four years later in Iraq; the billion-dollar brushoff; Mr. Giuliani goes south; a bad choice, a quick exit.
Bridge: E2 Weather: B8 Crossword: E6 TV Listings: E8
